Chapter 2.53


Late April 1439, Afternoon


The sunlight slants through the high windows of the Alcázar's council chambers, casting long rectangles across the parchment-strewn table where the three architects' drawings are spread. The Madrid plan—your great symbol of imperial ambition rendered in ink and vision—has just received your final approval. Maestro Lorenzo is already rolling up his practical construction diagrams, while Maestro Giorgio lingers over the design sketches of the Iota Monument with the particular satisfaction of an artist who has found a patron worthy of his dreams. Maestro Willem stands apart, making notes on a wax tablet about water tables and drainage grades.


Álvaro de Luna remains seated at your right hand, his stylus already moving as he drafts preliminary notes for the Council of Realms charter you've commissioned. Queen Lucia watches the proceedings from her place beside you, her expression thoughtful—she raised concerns about the personal journey to Poland-Hungary earlier, and that matter remains unresolved, deferred until news arrives about Queen Elisabeth's child and whether Władysław III will secure the Hungarian throne to add to his Polish crown.


Isaac de Baeza stands near the door, ever watchful, his intelligence networks having delivered their reports on England's cold withdrawal, Burgundy's commercial pragmatism, and France's unexpected openness. The Ottoman assessment—Murad's patient expansion, his fleet doubling at Gallipoli, his eastern flank secured—hangs in the air like an unspoken urgency.

The week passes in the ordinary rhythms of court life. Lucía's pregnancy progresses well; she takes morning walks in the Alcázar gardens with Catalina, now seven years old and full of questions about everything. Fernando, nearly six, has begun his first formal lessons with a tutor—letters and numbers, the foundations of a prince's education. Four Crown Marshalls stand along one wall: Don Íñigo López de Orozco, the eldest and most experienced, his beard now shot through with grey; García Fernández de Villalobos, lean and watchful; Pedro Álvarez de Osorio, who arrived only last night with mud still on his boots; and Rodrigo de Perea, tanned dark from Granada's sun.

Don Íñigo steps forward and offers a brief bow. He is perhaps sixty now, a man who has spent his life in service to the crown in one capacity or another. His voice is measured, that of a man accustomed to weighing his words.


"Your Majesty honors us by asking."


He clasps his hands behind his back. "In the field, the work is... variable. When I ride with an assessor to a minor lord's estate—a man who owes perhaps two thousand maravedís in back taxes—my presence usually suffices. The lord sees the royal badge, understands that defiance means escalation, and finds the money. Perhaps he grumbles. Perhaps he pays in installments. But he pays."


Don Íñigo pauses, his expression becoming more guarded.


"The great lords are another matter. When Diego's men"—he nods toward the assessors—"arrive at a duke's castle with discrepancies in hand, my badge means less. These men have their own armed retainers. Their stewards speak to me as an equal at best, an irritant at worst. They know that actual military enforcement requires Your Majesty's direct order, and they calculate—often correctly—that the crown has larger concerns than chasing them for what they owe."


He meets your eyes directly. "The system works, Your Majesty. It has recovered more revenue than anyone thought possible. But it works because most men choose to comply. Against those who choose otherwise and have the walls and swords to back that choice..." He spreads his hands. "I am one man with a badge."

When an assessor finds a discrepancy in a Mendoza vassal's accounts, I do not ride out with threats. I send word to the family's head, and the matter is resolved quietly. Honor is preserved. García Fernández de Villalobos, the marshall from León, speaks up unbidden. "And even among the houses that joined, Your Majesty, the younger sons and distant cousins do not always feel bound by what the family head agreed to. I have had... awkward encounters."

The assessor requested documentation. The steward promised to search the archives. Weeks passed. The documentation never arrived."


Don Íñigo stops pacing.


"So the assessor requested my involvement. I rode to the estate myself—three days' travel—and presented myself at the gate. I was received courteously. Fed well. Given a fine room. The lord was unfortunately away hunting. The steward repeated his claims about the privilege. I asked to see the original document. He said it was stored at another property. I said I would wait."


A dry smile crosses his face.


"I waited nine days, Your Majesty. Nine days of excellent hospitality and vague assurances. When the document finally appeared, it was genuine—but it granted exemption on grain exports, not wool. A simple error, the steward said. These old documents are so difficult to interpret."


He spreads his hands. "What was I to do? I could not arrest a duke's steward for creative reading. I issued a formal finding that the exemption did not apply and the sum was owed. The steward thanked me graciously and said he would consult with his lord."


"Three months later, after two more letters from Diego's office and a suggestion that the matter might be raised with Your Majesty directly, the house paid. In full. With no admission of wrongdoing and a letter expressing surprise that there had been any confusion."


Don Íñigo meets your eyes. "We recovered the money. But I spent nine days in a castle being fed roast boar while a steward played games with me.
